div.p: 1. V. Wednesday.

In visiting my garden and Nursery, my attention is still arrested by my seedling trees, although my experience has sufficiently proved, that upon this labour all my time and interest is wasted— I have trees of five successive years from the seed; of which one Mazzard Cherry, two Apricots and two or three peach trees shew blossoms—of last years growth there are numbers living of various sizes and strange shapes, and many dead— The nettle trees so promising in their appearance the last Season are all dead— The Sweet gum and willow Oaks, dead—the Honey locust, beginning to shew vegetation— The Ashes alive and promising— Many of the yearling Oaks looking well— Peaches, Cherries, Apples alive, and wanting to be trimmed— 3. Apples, and three pears, budded in 1831. promising. I had the Lima-beans given me by Dr Mease; sown— The old dead English walnut cut down for firewood— The two Currant-bushes from the seed, living— Others barely out of the ground in the boxes— The Strawberries, scarcely beginning to spread— I have in the garden and nursery, I suppose a hundred Apple seeds, and cherry stones, just up, scarcely yet able to discriminate them from one another— I prune freely the trees of two and three years standing— Deacon Spear came and settled with me, for the Notes due by him for wood on the Sales of last Autumn— I had also much Conversation with him upon the Parish debt— Nothing done— The Parish Treasurer inactive: the Collector delinquent. Deacon Spear made an arrangement with me for several parcels of my lands for the ensuing year. After dinner I walked down to the Mount Wollaston farm— My Orchard planted in 1830. is in little better condition than my other rural undertakings— Almost every one of my Seedlings has perished— Of the border of forest-trees scarcely one is left— They have all been extirpated by the frost, or smothered by rank growths of weeds— I met Alpheus Spear who was going to Dorchester, and continued my walk down to Rock-Island, where I met Luther Spear— He shewed me the whole range of fence which he said he had set out, and for which he calls upon me to pay. I saw it all, and asked what he would wish to charge me for it— He said about twenty-five dollars but afterwards admitted that might be too much— He said he would talk it over with his brother Alpheus, and then let me know the result— I walked home, and wrote all the Evening.
2. V:15 Thursday

list.item: C. F. Adams— Wife and Child

div.p:
My Son Charles, with his family came out from Boston, to pass the Summer, or a portion of it with us. Dr George Parkman came out with him, and walked back, refusing to stay and dine with us— His principal object seemed to be to ascertain whether I would accept an invitation to an Evening party at his house to meet Mr and Miss Kemble— He said the young Lady was desirous of being introduced to me— And I could but say that it would be very pleasing to me— She comes as an extraordinary personage— A young woman little more that twenty-two years of age, performing the first female parts of the drama, both in Tragedy and Comedy; and having herself at the age of sixteen written a Tragedy called Francis the first, which has been eminently successful She has also written much miscellaneous and fugitive poetry which is greatly admired— Withal a most affectionate and profitable daughter, to her father, whom she has relieved from great pecuniary embarrassments—perfectly unexceptionable in her deportment, and regular in attendance upon religious duties— A niece of Mrs Siddons, and of John Kemble—daughter of Charles Kemble and of Miss De Camp, she frequents here the most respectable Societies, and has elevated her
profession to the standard of the most liberal— As a sort of a personage myself, of the last century, I was flattered by the wish of this blossom of the next age, to bestow some of her fresh fragrance upon the antiquities of the past—and I answered Dr. Parkman accordingly. After dinner I had a visit from the present Lieutenant Governor of the Commonwealth, Mr Armstrong, who thanked me for several public documents, which I sent to him during the late Session of Congress, and with whom I had a long conversation upon nullification and the Colonization Society— Mr E. Price Greenleaf came, and viewed my garden and Nursery and promised to engraft apples and pears upon some of my young Stocks— I observe that the red Oak seedlings flourish the most and the white Oaks the least of any of my forest trees— Cherries the most and pears the least of my fruit-trees— The new Seedlings suffer by the drought.
3. V. Friday.

This old Revolutionary soldier from Marshfield came here again about his Pension, but he is so superannuated that he can give no corrected account of his Services— I questioned him particularly with regard to the time for which he was engaged under his several enlistments; but it was to no purpose. I finally told him that I would write to Washington, and endeavour to obtain from the Office of the Clerk of the House of Representatives his papers, to have them laid before the Secretary of War— I wrote to the Secretary of War, and sent him the papers relating to the claim of Ebenezer Standish; and reminding him of the claims of Corbin Barnes, Caleb Raymond and Lemuel Raymond—and I wrote also to John A. Smith, requesting him to draw upon me for the remainder of the debt due to him, by the bequest in my father’s Will— Spent much of the morning in my Garden and Nursery— I have a succession of seedling trees, from five years old to seeds just up, sown last Summer and Autumn, and this Morning I sow’d a row of white beech seeds, and mazzard cherry stones which have been kept over the winter, and of which I conclude that none will come up— Of the first vegetation of this year, nothing appears yet, but the seed leaves of Apples and Cherries. Sometimes the cherry stone itself, and the apple seed come out of the ground, cast off their broken shells, and expand to seed leaves— Several of those which had come up are already dead. I have a row of red, and a row of black Oaks, of which I planted the Acorns at the same time the 8th. of October 1831. The red Oaks have a growth of the last Season, twice at least upon the average, greater than that of the black— I have as yet no appearance from Acorns, nor even from any Peach-stone, planted the last Autumn— The Apricot-trees suffer greatly— White Elms grow with great rapidity— So do the English Oaks, but they get Winter-killed to the roots, and then grow up scrubby. Mr G. W. Beale spent the Evening with us— Charles went in to Boston, and returned to dine.
4. V. Saturday.

A Messenger came this morning with a letter from the Revd. Mr C. Brooks, of Hingham, dated at Weymouth announcing the death of my kinsman Cotton Tufts, with an invitation to his funeral, Monday next at three in the afternoon— He was first cousin to my mother, and the last remnant of that generation in my family—Thaxter’s—Mrs S. A. Otis and Mrs Patton Hall excepted— Charles dined in Boston and came back about dusk of Eve— Mr and Mrs Treadway came out from Boston to visit us, with Louisa C. Smith— Mrs Treadway is my brother Charles’s eldest daughter Susan Boylston, whose first husband was Lieutenant Clarke of the U.S. Navy— She was married a few days since at the house of her Sister Mrs. Alexr. B. Johnson, at
Utica, State of New-York— They are paying a short visit to her friends here. I received this Morning two Letters for Mrs Ann Adams my brother Thomas’s widow, from her sons Lieutenant Thomas B. and Cadet Isaac Hull—which I took to her this Evening. Her Sister, Mrs Greenough is with her.— The Barn was removed from the Hill opposite to the House, and set up in the yard, near the two others.— I gave a couple of hours to my garden and Nursery, pruning my seedling trees, and making useless observations— I set down in the ground, by way of experiment two twigs of Button-wood, to see if they would take root— One that I set out last Summer has failed— That which I set out in November 1830 is alive, and about putting forth leaves—
5. V.20. Sunday.

Heard Mr Gannett of Cambridgeport; this Morning from 2. Peter 1.16. “For we have not followed cunningly devised fables, when we made known unto you the power and coming of our Lord Jesus Christ, but were eye-witnesses of his Majesty”—and in the afternoon from Luke 12.51. “Suppose ye that I am come to give peace on earth? I tell you Nay; but rather division.” Mr Gannett dined with us—he is a young man of intelligent, but I think of anxious and melancholy disposition. He has difficulties with his Parish, and is much alarmed at the rapid progress of infidelity— It is indeed exceedingly remarkable that the state of profound peace and universal tranquility which for the last fifteen years has prevailed in this Country, has bred a portentous indifference to the military Spirit, and to religion— Within the last two years it has spread all over the Country to an extent which I can hardly realize— Mr Gannett appears to be under great discouragement, and dejection of Spirits— He told us that he had asked for a dismission from his parish; but did not say whether they had agreed to the proposal— John Kirk, arrived this afternoon with the Carriage and Horses— He left Washington last Tuesday— My wife sent him forward, intending to come on herself the next day— He was to wait for her at New-York—but on his arrival there, Mr John A. Smith received a Letter from my Son John directing that Kirk should proceed hither, without waiting for her, she being somewhat unwell, and having postponed her departure from Washington, for a few days.— I read the 10th. and last Sermon of Vol. 2. of Saurin, upon the necessity of progressive improvement Much time was likewise absorbed, in searching authorities for the definition of the word orphan. Eschines and Euripides, the Greek Testament and the Septuagint Psalms are the chief ones.
6. IV:30. Monday.

Received a Letter from my dear wife, who was taken ill, on the day when she intended to have left Washington, and was obliged to postpone for some days her departure— Charles went to Boston. Mr Otis the Translator of Botta’s History of the American Revolution, brought a manuscript translation which he has made of Cicero’s Offices, and others of his moral Treatises, concerning which he asked for my opinion—whether I thought the publication of it would have an effect unfavourable to his literary reputation— He read to me five chapters of the third Book of the Offices, which I thought very well done— He left the manuscript with me and I promised to read it, and give him my opinion of it— He said he had now an application for a third Edition of his Translation of Botta, for which he is to receive 2000 dollars— That he had received 4000 dollars for the first Edition, and 500 dollars for the second. The edition now proposed, is to
be in Stereotype— Mr Otis said that Mr John Pickering had had the manuscript three weeks in his possession, and approved of every part of the Translation. I said there would be a difficulty with regard to the word honestum, which he renders by the word honest. It has not the same signification. He said he was sensible of this difficulty, and it had been mentioned to him, by Mr Pickering, but there was no other word, in English which could be substituted for it. I advised that in using it, he should give an explanatory note— We had an early dinner, and I went with Charles’s wife, and Mrs T. B. Adams whom I took up at her house to Weymouth, and attended the funeral of my kinsman Cotton Tufts; a man who has lived nearly to the age of four-score; having had a liberal education, but never emerged from obscurity and retirement. He was entombed, in the same yard, and near the spot, where fifty six years ago, I followed my mother’s mother to the grave— Without returning to the House, we came back over the Quincy point Bridge, and left Mrs Adams at her house— Charles brought me from Boston Potter’s Euripides, and a note from Dr George Parkman, with Miss Fanny Kemble’s Tragedy of Francis the first, which together with the Memoir of her life I read this Evening— I had spent two hours of the morning, as I now do almost every day in the garden and Nursery.— My Apple-seeds and Cherry-stones sown last Autumn come up very slowly and very thin, excepting a single row near the bottom of the Nursery; all of which are out of the ground— This day was the first appearance of a peach. I prune the trees of former years with unsparing hand. Horse Chesnut leaves are opening; plums and cherries in full blossom; pears and apples blossoming—
7. IV:45 Tuesday.

Change of weather again, and after lighting a fire in my chamber this morning, I had the Thermometer in the course of the day at 90. There was this Evening a slight sprinkling of rain; but the drought, is for the Season excessive, and extends as far South as Virginia— I had a morning visit from Dr Richmond, a Clergyman residing at Dorchester. After dinner Mr Price Greenleaf came and grafted for me two Pear Stocks in the Garden, and severalApplestocks in the Nursery— I have three horse-Chesnuts, rising out of the ground since yesterday; and a very few Apple-seeds and wild-cherries coming up here and there— The Nettle-tree gives its first sign of life— The red and black Oaks open their leaves— The Chesnuts and Elms the same— I removed a sucker from one of the red Cherry-trees to another part of the garden— I have two Currant bushes from seeds, growing well. The Strawberries spread very slowly—but live— Not one of the Stones and acorns, which I specially staked out last Autumn has come up— Much of this day, morning and afternoon was absorbed in the Garden— But I answered a Letter from Daniel L. Gray, inviting my attendance at the anniversary of the New-York Young Men’s society; which is auxiliary to the American Young Men’s Society, for moral and intellectual improvement— I am obliged to decline attendance at their meeting, which is to be on the 15th. of this Month.
8. IV.45. Wednesday.

Charles went to Boston, and returned to dinner. The day was intensely warm, and the afternoon oppressively sultry— I visited the garden and Nursery, where the progress of vegetation affords me pleasure, and acquires for the time, a very disproportionate interest— It is also useful bodily exercise— I have planted in two rows in the Garden a number of Spanish Chesnuts which Charles brought out from Boston, but which will probably not come up— With them are a number of Cherry-Stones and white Beech seeds kept over winter which have doubtless
perished in like manner. My experience convinces me, that the only proper mode of raising trees, whether for fruit or for the forest, is from the seed; but that it is an art, requiring skill, and a continued course of minute observation—a long and persevering pursuit of the object— Patience in waiting for results—fortitude to bear disappointments with good temper, and judgment and reflection to draw profitable facts from observed phenomena— After six years of persevering experiment, I am yet to learn how to sow or plant the seed, so that any considerable portion of it shall come up— And how to protect it when up from frost—from the heat of the Sun; from insects, and from mice— I answered Letters this day from Judge Hopkinson, and from Robert Walsh— And I read several chapters of Mr Otis’s translation of Cicero’s Offices; comparing them with the Original and with the German and French Translations— Otis translates nothing but the words, and preserves entirely the Latin idiom— His book therefore will be scarcely more intelligible to the English reader, than the Latin itself— The heat of the weather reduced me to idleness, from dinner till Night.
9. IV.45. Thursday.

I spend two hours or more every Morning, in my garden and Nursery. Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— I received a Letter from my wife, dated last Sunday; mentioning her intention to leave Washington the next Morning, and expecting to arrive here to-morrow— After dinner I rode on horseback to Dorchester and visited Mr John Bailey— Returned home at the dusk of Evening— I wrote a short Letter to my Son John at Washington, enclosing a power of Attorney to him, from Mrs Parkman, to receive Money, due her, upon an award of the Commission, for claims upon Denmark— A person by the name of Aaron Smith called on me this Evening— He said he was born and bred at Athol in the County of Worcester—that he now resided at Boston; was a Carpenter by trade, and having some business at Quincy had come to see me from mere curiosity. I read a few pages of the life of Sir Isaac Newton by David Brewster; but time flies, and my hours waste away, leaving no traces for Memory— Last Monday a second trial was made to elect members of Congress for three of the twelve Districts of this Commonwealth— The first, third, and ninth— Unsuccessfully in all.
10. V. Friday.

I was called in from my inspection of vegetation in my garden and Nursery, this morning by two Men, going round for subscriptions to raise money, they say 5500 dollars to build a bridge, and open a road from Commercial point in Dorchester, to Boston; a project of which I heard much some 25 years back, but which since that time has slumbered till now. They supposed it might shorten and improve the road from my house to Boston so much that I should be willing to subscribe something for it; but I declined— I received a Letter from John A. Smith notifying me, that he had drawn upon me for 960 dollars, the whole balance due him, upon the bequest to him in my father’s Will, as I had proposed to him by Letter a few days since. At the same time I received from the Cashier of the Suffolk Bank in Boston, notice that the draft was payable— Charles therefore went into Boston, with my Check upon the U.S. Branch Bank, and took up the draft— He came home to dine— Luther Spear came with a bill of 14:75 for the fence, for which he has had a claim upon me, which I took for consideration— He spoke also of purchasing part of my Land at the foot of Penn’s Hill, or taking a Lease of
my farm there for five years, upon which we shall converse further hereafter.— John Kirk went with the Carriage to Dedham, and about six O’Clock this Evening, my dear wife arrived, with John’s Child Louisa, and a Chambermaid, Margaretbut without either Mrs Nowlan or Mrs Pitts— Mrs Adams was much fatigued and exhausted, having travelled from Washington here since Monday afternoon— Antoine Giusta came with her as far as New-York; and Mr Wallack of Washington, from thence to Dedham— She was quite ill this Evening; and fainted before going to bed— But was afterwards better— The Newspapers contain accounts of a personal assault by the late lieutenant Randolph of the navy, upon President Jackson, on board a Steamboat at Alexandria— He simply tweaked him by the nose, and went away— Jackson was much disposed to chastise him with his cane—but Randolph got away without even being arrested by the President’s retinue— A bench warrant from the Circuit Court, and a Justice’s warrant were issued against Randolph, but he got out of their reach, and out of the district into Virginia, before they could be served— A President of the United States pulled by the nose, is a new incident in the History of this Country; and as he himself has countenanced personal violence against members of Congress, he will not meet with much sympathy. The law provides no special penalty for this offence,—the judicial proof of which would be a hundred times severer punishment upon the sufferer than upon the culprit— Randolph may run a risk of being mobbed, and certainly would be so, in a place where the President should be very popular— He is not so now, in the district of Columbia.
11. IV.45. Saturday.

In my Morning visitation of my Garden and Nursery, I took up and transplanted a Plum tree, the only one raised from the Stone of a multitude that I have planted, and which had grown up between a Peach tree, and a Cherry or Apricot, and now too near to both— As none of my seeds specially staked out have come up, I probed the ground where I had planted a whole wood house apple, and found it in full vegetation, four or five inches beneath the service— It would probably never have made its way to the surface, or if at-all, so late in the Season that the plant could not have had time to outgrow the destruction of the next winter’s frost— My sweet gum tree and one willow oak, have survived the last winter— I went into Boston, and dined at Dr George Parkman’s, with Mr Charles Kemble, and his daughter Frances Ann— Dr Parkman had made up this party on purpose to produce this Meeting. his brothers Francis and Daniel—Mr and Mrs R. G. Shaw, Judge Thacher, Mr and Mrs Theodore Lyman junr, and Mr and Mrs Alexander H. Everett were there. Dr Shattuck came in after dinner. I had much conversation with Miss Kemble, chiefly upon dramatic Literature; but it differed not from what it might have been with any well educated and intelligent young woman of her age— I spoke to her of some of her own poetical productions, but she did not appear inclined to talk of them— What she appeared chiefly to pride herself upon was feats of horsemanship. She said she had rode this Morning about thirty miles, and leaped over many fences and Stone walls— She said they expected to remain in this Country till about this time next year. I asked her if she had ever seen her Aunt Mrs Siddons upon the Stage— She had not but had heard her read Shakespear. She had known her only as a very good woman. She observed that she herself had been chiefly educated, and spent the greater part of her life in France, and until a very few years since had never had an idea of going upon the Stage herself— I had called at judge Hall’s before going to dinner, and I came home between ten and eleven at night.
12. V:15. Sunday.

Heard Mra stranger to me, this morning from Acts 20.24. [“]But none of these things move me, neither count I my life dear unto myself, so that I might finish my course with joy; and the ministry which I have received of the Lord Jesus, to testify the gospel of the grace of God.” and in the afternoon, from Luke 17.21—“The kingdom of God is within you”— The Congregation was very thin— The preacher sensible, but cold— Mr Degrand came out from Boston—dined and spent the day with us— I read the first Sermon of the third Volume of Saurin, from Matthew 16.26. “what shall a man give in exchange for his Soul?”—the subject is the preciousness of the Soul.
13. VI. Monday.

Charles went to Boston, and returned at Night— Mr Jotham Lincoln came to enquire concerning the state of his claim in Congress— I told him that a Bill in his favour had been reported by the Committee of Claims early in January, but that the days usually devoted to private business, having been wasted upon the Tariff Bill, his claim had not been reached— And I promised to give the earliest attention to it at the next Session of Congress— Mr T. Greenleaf called on me at four this afternoon, and I went with him to the Parish-Meeting, which was not numerously attended— I was chosen Moderator— Votes were passed 1. Authorizing the Treasurer to sell the 30 pews remaining unsold, for 3000 dollars if so much can be obtained for them. 2. To revoke the permission to the purchasers of pews, partly paid for, to hold them, by paying interest on the balances due upon them— 3. Directing the Treasurer to require payment or satisfactory security for the balances due, on or before the first of July next— 4. That the 3. Assessors, the 3. Deacons and the Treasurer be a Committee to engage preachers to assist Mr Whitney, in the performance of his parochial duties. and the Meeting adjourned to the first Saturday in July at 4 O’Clock in the afternoon. Deacon Spear, Captain Souther, General Taylor, and Harvey Field, are the principal managers at Parish Meetings— It was near seven O’Clock when the Meeting adjourned.
14. IV.45. Tuesday.

Promises of rain in the weather, with little performance— I receive Letters, which it is difficult to answer, and sometimes they absorb an undue proportion of my time— Shortly before I left Washington, I received from R. Newman of Romney, Virginia, a View of the Solar System in 24. Folio pages, with three or four Sheets of Diagrams, containing a theory of astronomy, which he put under my protection— I brought it with me from Washington, but have not had time to examine it— This day I received from the author a second Letter, enquiring if I had received the other— There came also a Letter from R: W. Middleton of Gettysburg Pennsylvania, enquiring my opinion, whether seceding Free-Masons are justifiable in disclosing the Secrets of Masonry— And a Letter from Mr John Angier of Medford, giving the opinion that my nephew and namesake, now at his school, is not suited in disposition or capacity for a College Education— These are all subjects that absorb time and meditation. In my garden and nursery I found vegetation much at a stand—discovered new shoots of two seedling trees, but not so distinct that I could tell what they were— The morning wasted away—and the afternoon till near Sunset, when I walked to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and gave her a Letter from her son Thomas, now at Pittsburg— Charles’s child is confined to the chamber, with a severe cold and cough.
15. V. Wednesday.

The Season is exceedingly dry— There was last Night and this morning a very light warm rain, the effect of which upon vegetation was visible— I spent about three hours of this Morning in my garden and Nursery— I do so almost every morning, and the only apology that I can make for this waste of time, is that it serves for bodily exercise— I wish also to use it in observing the phenomena of vegetation, and thence to draw useful conclusions— But this is a source only of disappointment— I commenced this morning the labour of eradicating weeds, which will give me constant and laborious exercise— I found this morning at the bottom of the Nursery three seedling cherry trees, in a range where I have been three years endeavouring to raise them without success— There was one came up there last Summer but it perished— I ascertained by turning up the ground of a whole dwarf Apple, which I had specially staked out, that it has vegetated, but I probably destroyed the Seedlings— My Nettle-trees which I headed down thinking them dead have put out shoots in profusion— The Night-beetle has topped off all the shoots of my red Oaks, without sparing one of them— I received a Letter from the Secretary of War, enclosing Certificates of Pensions for Corbin Barnes, Lemuel Raymond, and Caleb Raymond which I enclosed immediately to William Thomas at Plymouth, and for Ebenezer Standish, which I sent to Jonathan Parker at Plympton— I also answered the Letter of R. W. Middleton, and that of W. H. Seward, with one of introduction to General La Fayette— Mr and Mrs N. L. Frothingham came from Boston, and took tea, with us— In the Evening I called upon my neighbour Mr G. W. Beale, who last Sunday dislocated or sprained his ancle, but says he set it immediately himself— Met Mr Thomas Greenleaf there— Charles removed most of the books which have been received from Washington, over to the Farm House.
16. IV.45. Thursday.

I read Mr Robert Newman’s Views of the Solar System, and answered his Letter, proposing to present his paper to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences— He considers the Newtonian doctrine of attraction and gravitation as inadequate to explain the phenomena of Astronomy. He supposes an elastic gazeous principle necessary to account for the motion of matter, and thinks Newton’s theory defective in assuming that the Sun is stationary. I am not sure that Newton’s system does assume or require this— I got engaged this morning in some enquiries respecting the Chronology and History of the books of Ezra and Nehemiah, and the names of Cyrus, Darius, Ahasuerus and Artaxerxes, contained in them— The Assyrian, Syrian, Babylonian, Median and Persian Monarchies, are blended together in my mind, so that I have no distinct idea of their history, nor indeed of the Geography of the Countries where they existed— I looked into Lenglet du Fresnoy’s Tablettes Chronologiques, and into the Tables of the Dictionnaire Historique, where I found some information, and indications where more is to be found; but it consumes time, and leaves me still to search and read— I laboured also in my Garden and Nursery, and began upon the extirpation of weeds. I observe the difference in the vegetation of the Shell bark and pignut walnut trees— This afternoon I gathered a few elm seeds, and planted a row of them in the garden— The horse chesnut tree in front of my chamber window is in full blossom.
17. V:15. Friday.

Much of the morning was occupied in weeding my Nursery, the weather being still so cool, that I could work there. After dinner I walked to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and gave her a Letter from her Son Isaac Hull at West Point— Her other Son John Quincy had just come in from the School at Medford, where there is now a vacation— I gathered a few Elm seeds, which have fallen from the Trees— Michaux says they are ripe from the 15th. of May to the 1st. of June; but it is scarcely conceivable that so mere an Atom in appearance should live in the ground to become an Elm tree— I pursued my enquiries into the Chronology of the books of Ezra, Nehemiah, and Esther, without coming to any satisfactory result— My wife was very unwell this afternoon and Evening— Mr G. W. Beale requested me to draw up a paper containing my proposal, with regard to the debt due from the Congregational Society of this place to me, which I did this Evening— Charles set out a number of Fir, and sugar maple trees which he has purchased in Boston; in the enclosure East of the House.
18. V:30. Saturday.

Midsummer heat— It was yesterday so cold that I was obliged to make a fire in my chamber to read and write with comfort; and this morning after going into my nursery to continue the process of extirpating weeds I was obliged to retreat from the scorching heat of the Sun, back into the house— This is the constant alternation which in this Climate passes for the Spring of the year— I finished sowing the single row of Elm seeds, which I had commenced last Thursday—and prepared the ground for a second row. Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— Deacon Josiah Adams was here this afternoon, and I settled accounts with him for rent of a pasture, and for wood which he cut and carted for me last winter, and this Spring— I finished a fourth Letter to Edward Livingston, and wrote a short one to my Son John— But my time slides inconceivably away. I plunged this day into Beloe’s Herodotus, Justinus and Count John Potocki’s Principes de Chronologie, to ascertain the Times of the Events recorded in the Books of Ezra and Nehemiah— I have now a more distinct idea of them fixed in my mind than I had ever been able to obtain before— I sent this morning to Mr G. W. Beale, the Parish Treasurer, my proposals respecting their debt— My wife is better.
19. IV:15. Sunday.

Heard Mr Whitney, this morning from John 1.46. “Philip saith unto him come and see.” and in the afternoon from 1. Corinthians 14.40. “Let all things be done decently and in order.”— I read the second Sermon of the 3d. volume of Saurin—upon the penitence of the Sinner woman Luke 7.36–50. a very edifying discourse, remarkable especially for the statement of a great controversial question, whether the sins of this woman were forgiven because she loved much; or whether she loved much because her sins were forgiven— That is which was the cause, and which the effect— The narrative certainly gives occasion for such a question— The repentance of the woman is proportioned to the magnitude of her Sins, and her pardon is obtained by the sincerity of her repentance, and the warmth of her affection.— She is saved by her works, and she is saved by her faith— I looked into the Jewish Antiquities of Josephus of the French Translation by Arnaud d’Andilly, to clear up the Chronology of the Books of Ezra and Nehemiah— But Josephus multiplies difficulties— He says it was Cambyses the Son of Cyrus who arrested the building of the Temple— That Cambyses died after a reign of six years, and that after an
usurpation by the Magi of one year, Darius the son of Hystaspes was chosen king. That under him Zorobabel rebuilt the Temple of Jerusalem— That Xerxes was the son of Darius, and commissioned Ezra and Nehemiah, and that Cyrus, called by the Greeks Artaxerxes, was the Son of Xerxes, and the husband of Esther— The Chronology at the end of Saci’s french Translation of the Bible says that Darius Hystaspes was the Ahasuerus of Esther, and Artaxerxes Longimanus the king who commissioned Ezra and Nehemiah— That this could not be Xerxes seems apparent for he reigned only 20 years and Nehemiah speaks of the 32d year of the king. To reconcile the Bible names and Chronology with those of the profane historians must be given up as a desperate job— The morning of this day was so warm, that I totally dismissed my winter clothing; there was a sudden and instantaneous change this afternoon, by the wind’s coming round to the East— Very little rain.
20 V Monday.

Cold Easterly wind, cloudy, and occasional light rain— I went to Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s, and acknowledged as one of the Executors of Ward N. Boylston, a deed of Lands in the Town of Westminster in the County of Worcester, which Charles had drawn, and which he now took to Boston— He returned home to dinner. My Nephew and namesake was here— He has no disposition to go to College— I asked him what he wished to do— He said to go into a Store— I had proposed to give him a classical education, but cannot controul the course of Nature— Luther Spear came, and I settled with him his claim for fencing at Rocky Island on the Mount Wollaston farm— The justice of this claim is exceedingly doubtful; but in all questions of pecuniary interest, with a poor man—where there is doubt, the equitable rule is to yield rather than contend. The maxim of Wisdom would be, concede everything to the poor, which they claim of right. I worked in my Nursery garden Morning and afternoon— The Seedlings of the present Season have ceased coming up; and the heat of the Sun has killed so many of them, that it is doubtful whether any of them will survive the Season— I gathered a few Elm seeds, and sowed a second row of the seeds in the garden— The Horse Chesnut, Lilac and Strawberry are in profuse blossom— A single peach has come up in the garden and one in the Nursery, an Apple bud inserted by Price Greenleaf in August 1831 and which we thought had failed, shoots out since he grafted the same Stock— Several of his grafts are also vegetating— I pursued my Chronological enquiries till I became unable to determine whether the Ahasuerus of Ezra, and of Esther, was Darius Hystaspes, Xerxes, or Artaxerxes Longimanus— Dallied with Josephus, Herodotus and Justinus, till the day was gone, and in the Evening by way of variety read part of Potter’s Translation of the Bacchae of Euripides.
21. V 45. Tuesday.

A Mr Pearce, collector of taxes at Milton, called upon me for a highway tax, assessed upon me for the Penny-ferry lot of Saltmarsh of 2 1/2 acres which I own in that town— This high way tax is an extra burden, besides those of the Union, State, County, Town and Parish. The morning was cold and rainy—the afternoon sultry without clearing away, but I worked in the garden both parts of the day— Received a Letter from my Son John in his own hand writing— The first for nearly a year past— It gave me a cheering hope.
I wrote short Letters to Judge Hopkinson and Dr Waterhouse, and towards Evening took to Mrs T. B. Adams a Letter from her son Joseph H, the Midshipman, dated at Port Mahon the 17th. of February last— Mrs Adams told me she proposed to go with her Son John Quincy to Medford to-morrow— I planted a row of berries of the Holly, and weeded My dwarf apple has put forth one seed— Charles set out three cedars in my Nursery— I finished my Chronological researches, to elucidate the Books of Ezra, Nehemiah, and Esther; and also Potter’s translation of the Bacchae of Euripides— Pentheus maddened by Bacchus is slain by his own mother, frantic as one of the Bacchae, because he treats the God with contempt
22. IV.15. Wednesday.

Ebenezer Adams brought me this morning a bill for carting sundry loads of gravel to raise the causeway at the bridge over the brook in the rear of the house at the foot of Penn’s Hill, which I settled and paid— Immediately after dinner Mr Odiorne and Mr Lamb, came from the Anti-Masonic State Committee, to invite me to deliver an Address or Oration to them on the fourth of July, which for various reasons I declined— Odiorne asked me whether I thought it would be advisable for them to omit the delivery of an Oration for this year, and I answered that I did. I went with Luther Spear to the farm at the foot of Penn’s Hill, and over the grounds. Spear wants to purchase part of the land there to build a house upon it, but expects to have it very cheap— I met there Lewis Bass and his father Jonathan Bass at work, mending the Stone wall— Lewis Bass has a house there and about two thirds of an Acre of land which he wishes to sell, and for which he asks 1800 dollars— Returning home I stop’d at Mr Brigham’s shop, and received one years interest upon my Canal Notes.— I made some small examination of the receipts and expenditures of the Canal; and was not entirely satisfied with the management of the affairs of the Corporation— Mr Brigham offered me three shares and one Note, for sale at a very moderate price— There is every prospect of appretiation of the property; but it is prudent to avoid holding too large a stake in a small corporation— I walked home, and was in the Evening so thoroughly wearied that I was unable to read— Having this day got through the Historical books of the Old Testament I shall suspend the further reading of the common English Bible, to take up Charles Thomson’s Translation of the Septuagint.
23. IV. Thursday

I commenced reading this morning Charles Thomson’s Translation of the Septuagint Bible, published at Philadelphia in 1808. in four Octavo Volumes— It has no preface or introduction— No heading to the Chapters—no Notes— It is a mere literal Translation of the Septuagint—the Greek Translation of the Hebrew Bible said to have been made by order of Ptolemy Philadelphus; by 70 Translators and completed in 70 days for which reason it is called the Septuagint— The French Translation of Saci, is made from this Book— I propose reading four chapters every day, which allowing for the occasional interruptions when I have not the book, will carry me through it if life and health permit, in one year— Charles and his wife went to Boston, and returned towards Evening— I worked in my Nursery and garden hoeing up weeds in the morning but after dinner, the warmth of the Sun only permitted me to gather, and plant a new row of Elm seeds— I have also planted a row of berries of the Holly, and one of the Tupelo; and I sawed off at the stump an Apple-tree in the Garden, which has been destroyed by the Borer worm. After dinner
I read five Chapters of G. A. Otis’s Translation of Cicero’s Offices, which I compared with the Original, with Guthries English and two French Translations, and in the Evening I read part of the Ion of Euripides in Potter— I despatched to B. F. Hallett, Letter 4. to E. Livingston.
24. IV:15. Friday.

Samuel Belcher of Randolph, a Soldier of the Revolution, came with a Certificate for a pension, under the Act of 7. June 1832, for 80 dollars a year; but he said his pay was 8 dollars a month, and his pension ought to be 96 dollars a year. He wished me to recover it for him, and I promised to write to the Secretary of War upon the Subject— I told him I expected to receive an answer in about 3 weeks, and asked him to call again about that time— Morning visit from Mr Bailey and Mr Morton, who appears to be discouraged upon the subject of Antimasonry. Mr Bayley said Mr Ward of New-York, the Editor of the Whig Newspaper had been recently in Boston, and was for giving up the ship and making terms with Governor Marcy.— Solomon Thayer was here this afternoon. Says he has two Acres of ground covered with his new grain, with which he continues to be as successful as ever— Mine, attempted by both my Tenants has totally failed— Mr Thayer has also an Application before the Secretary of War, for a pension, concerning which I promised to write to the Secretary to hasten his decision— Mrs Foster and her daughter Louisa were here this afternoon but I did not see them— My nephew John Quincy was here this Evening: and a man brought me a periodical pamphlet called the abolitionest commenced by the Anti-Slavery Society— The first number of a monthly publication to which he solicited my subscription but I declined— I worked in my garden morning and afternoon. I find the labour excellent exercise for my health; but for almost every other purpose terminating in constant disappointment and mortification— Absorbing too an unreasonable portion of my time— I read 5. Chapters of G. A. Otis’s translation of Cicero’s Offices compared with the original, with Guthrie’s English, Garve’s German, and Barrett and Brosselard’s French Translations.
25. IV:30. Saturday.

The differing Chronologies of the Hebrew and Septuagint Bibles absorb my time. The 5th. Chapter of Genesis contains the genealogies and chronology from the creation to the flood— The 11th. Chapter, from the flood to the birth of Abram. The Septuagint makes the whole 3434 years—the Hebrew Bible 1948— Here is a difference of 1486 years— The modern Systems of Chronology are generally founded upon the Hebrew text, but the phenomena of the Earth and the populousness of the antient Nations seem to require the more extended term— There can indeed be no authentic record of History, nor of proper names of much earlier date than the invention of Alphabetical writing— It is difficult to comprehend how there could be Language, or at any rate, Grammar before that time— The Hieroglyphics of Egypt were painted emblems— If Cadmus the Phenician was the inventor of the Alphabet, the Hebrew, must be a dialect of the oldest language extent— These enquiries are endless— I visited my garden and nursery morning and afternoon—finished the weeding of the central Alley— I make experiments of heading down trees, and cut off the willow tree in the Summer house cellar, of which I set out in the garden four
branches for Stocks— Mr Wallack of Washington was here this afternoon, and offered to take charge of any thing we might wish to send. He is to go from Boston, Monday Morning— He told me his father, Moses Wallack was yet living—very aged, and infirm— I wrote Letters to the Secretary of War, and to my Son John— Read 5 Chapters of the Offices.
26. IV:15. Sunday.

Heard Mr Whitney, this morning from 2. Timothy 4.6. “For I am now ready to be offered, and the time of my departure is at hand.”—and in the afternoon from 1. Chronicles 28.9.—[“]for the Lord searcheth all hearts, and understandeth all the imaginations of the thoughts: if thou seek him, he will be found of thee; but if thou forsake him he will cast thee off forever.”— The day was dull and gloomy though with very little rain, in short drizzling Showers— The auditory very small, both parts of the day.— My nephew and namesake dined with us— I read the 3d Sermon of the 3d. volume of Saurin, upon the accordance between Religion and Politicks— It is none of the best—delivered in May 1706 four days after the Battle of Ramilies, and its principal object is the refutation of Bayle’s paradoxical and heterodoxical opinion that a people could not subsist as a Government, and observe the principles of Christianity— Montesquieu has contested rather than refuted this opinion of Bayle— Saurin meets it with furious invective;—in the biographical dictionaries it is said that Bayle died in December 1706. this Sermon mentions him however as deceased before it was delivered— Here is a third Example added to those of Tillotson and Massillon, of the danger to a preacher who indulges himself in vituperation upon individuals— Bayle was a free thinker—perhaps an infidel; but how harmless to his reputation is this abuse of Saurin—a man whose reputation though yet high as an eloquent preacher is yet far below that of Bayle— I read also part of the Life of Pythagoras in the Bibliotheque des Philosophes— Mr Beale and his Son was here this Evening— He is going upon an excursion of a fortnight to Saratoga’s Springs— I was quite unwell.
27. IV:50. Monday.

Another gloomy day with an East wind and very little rain— Morning and afternoon in the garden and nursery—weeding—no new vegetation— After dinner I gathered an handful of Elm Seeds, strewed on the ground, fallen from the Trees, and planted them in Earthen Pots— The germ of the Elm is a small seed about as big as the head of a pin, covered with a cuticle, forming a round flat leaflet, about a quarter of an inch in diameter— They are now thickly strewed on the ground under the Trees— The colour of the covering pellicle has faded, but the germ at the centre is yet green— The ash has a similar germ under a cover of a different form— The germ of the Oak and that of the Chesnut are not larger, but they are enclosed in large pulpy acorns and nuts— It is said that the seeds of elms readily come up; but this is the first time I have had the opportunity of trying them. M’Mahon’s gardener’s Calendar says the seeds should be gathered when ripe and kept several days to dry— Then sown at broad cast, and covered not more than a quarter of an inch deep of Earth— Neither the drying, nor the sowing at Broad cast seems to be essential— I received from a person named Paine, of the Boston Advocate, a proof of my fourth Letter to Edward Livingston, which I revised and sent back— He writes me, that the Cover of the manuscript which I had directed to B. F. Hallett he found broken open at the Post-Office.
I read five chapters of Otis’s Translation of Cicero’s Offices, and the Original and corresponding English and French Translations; and part of Potter’s Translation of the Ion of Euripides.
28. V.30. Tuesday— Boston and back to Quincy.

Four Chapters of Charles Thomson’s Translation of the Septuagint Bible, with occasion reference to the common English Bible and to Hewlett’s Annotations, absorb too great a proportion of my time. Every morning I find myself led into enquiries from the pursuit of which I am obliged to desist. This morning I had the vocation of Abraham. I seek for the causes which have given to that Jewish People that transcendent influence which they have exercised over the History of mankind— It begins with Abraham—an emigrant from the Chaldean Country of Mesopotamia, a pastoral chieftain owning flocks and herds and rich in silver and gold, but owning no lands. He quits one Country and is promised another for his descendants— Yet the Assyrian, and Egyptian Monarchies then existed—and the descendants of Ham were in permanent possession of the land, which was to belong finally to the children of Israel. Here is a wide field of enquiry open— I went this morning with Charles to Boston, and after calling at Mr James H. Foster’s, and returning the visit of the Lieutt. Governor Samuel T. Armstrong who was not at home, I attended a Statute Meeting of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, when the Officers of the last year were re-elected— The nomination book for new members was lost. I presented the paper of Mr Newman of Virginia upon the Solar System, which was referred without reading to the publishing Committee— A new Volume of the Transactions was prepared for publication, and the price for it was fixed at four dollars— There were about fifteen members present; but excepting my communication, no approach was made to the consideration of any subject of a Scientific character. I moved that in the list of Members to be published with the new Volume, all honorific Titles should be dispensed with in designating domestic members—which was agreed to— The Meeting adjourned about one O’Clock, and I returned with Charles to Quincy to dine— After dinner I lounged about my garden and did nothing. Nor could I read but a few pages this Evening—
29. IV:10. Wednesday.

The weather continues cloudy and cold with Easterly winds, and occasional, but very light rains. I wade along with Charles Thomson’s Translation of the Septuagint— I have settled the Chronological questions as much to my satisfaction as I could expect— Mr Daniel Greenleaf was here this afternoon with Mrs Cranch, and Mrs Mary Dawes— I spent hours of the morning in the Nursery and of the afternoon in the Garden. I continue the labour of weeding while I may— My Strawberries which I raised from the seed in 1831. and transferred from the pot to the Bed last Summer have blossomed, and will bear this Season. But the wild plants which I brought from the Rail way in November 1830. have been totally smothered, by a spontaneous growth of red Clover—which with sundry weeds has wholly overspread the patch of ground. I gathered and planted a row of Elm Seeds— And after I had concluded that the putting forth of Seedlings had ceased for the year, I discovered a row of half a dozen Oaklings coming out of the ground, and as almost always
happens, in a totally unexpected place— I found in a box of dry sand, a heap of acorns, Shellbark walnuts and chesnuts which I had buried there last October, to keep them over winter, and which I had forgotten till now. Had they been planted when I first came home, they might have come to something— I deposited almost the whole of them in a heap at the corner of the Nursery— Some of the Horse-Chesnuts may come up.
30. IV:30. Thursday.

Rainy morning and cold— The weather cleared up this afternoon still cold, and leaving me with a rhumatic head-ache— I worked about 3 hours in my Nursery—the weeding of which yet gives me full occupation— After dinner I walked round to Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s wharf and landing place, and found that the large white-beech trees from which I gathered last Autumn a quantity of seeds, have been cut down— None of the Seeds have come up— M’Mahon says that the Field Mice, are excessively fond of them— Ebenezer Adams was here this afternoon, and notified me, that he had fire-wood for sale— My wife received a Letter from my Son John’s— He has been very ill, and last Sunday was yet confined to his bed— I am reading the life of Pythagoras in the Bibliotheque des Philosophes—Josephus, Herodotus, Goguet’s Origine des Loix, Otis’s translation of Cicero’s Offices, with the original and four other translations. Potter’s Translation of Euripides, and multitudes of pamphlets; of which scarcely a day passes without bringing me one or more. This is lamentable waste of Time.
31. IV:15. Friday.

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— After spending three hours of the morning in the Nursery, and planting one row of wintered walnuts in the garden, I employed the afternoon in writing, and took a very short walk just after Sunset— Three hours of exposure to the air, with the labour of weeding which produces profuse perspiration, is exercise enough for the day; and not too much. Almost every one of Mr Price Greenleaf’s grafts upon my apple and Pear trees have taken, and are putting forth shoots, and most of the buds—upon the same trees which had been inserted in August 1831. and which we thought had failed, are opening leaves, and putting out shoots— My seedling apples of the present year are perishing in the radiance of the Sun— The wild Cherries bear it much better— My seedling Strawberries are promising with blossoms, and I have high Blackberries, Currants and Grapes coming up— The Beetle bugs devour in the Night, the tops and leaves of my red Oaks— The Ash grows more beautifully than any other tree, and no Insect appears yet to attack it— My Walnut trees from the Pennsylvania Nut come out later than those from the Nuts of our own Soil. Charles is planting Larch, Fir, Spruce, red Cedar and Sugar Maple trees; all which I should be glad to raise from the seed. My two Willow Oaks, one sweet Gum, one Catalpa, and one Honey Locust are yet alive; as are four or five Nettle trees; one only of which has come up this Spring— We had morning visits from Judge Hall, and Mr John Gray; and in the afternoon from Miss Julia Gorham, and her brother— Mr Whitney called with his two daughters in the Evening— I finished reading the Life of Pythagoras.

Day. I rise usually between four and five O’Clock, and read four chapters of the Bible— Now Charles Thomson’s Translation of the Septuagint— Upon which I write a few short Notes— Breakfast between 7 and 8. Work or Loiter three hours in my Garden and Nursery— Then read and write in my Library-room till two— Dine; and after dinner, repair again to the garden and lounge, or to my Study, and read; for it is irksome to write— We have tea between six and seven in the Evening; then conversation and desultory reading till the Parish Bell at nine P.M. and soon after; all retire.
